div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,596] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: Russian Stream Navigation & Commercial Company.
div.p: Postal Service Accelerated
between Alexandria, Piraeus, Smyrna, Constantinople, and Odessa by the following recenlty built and perfectly equipped vessels:
Arrivals at Alexandria on Saturday afternoons.
Departures from Alexandria on Fridays at 10 a.m. Circular route between Alexandria, Port Said, the Syrian ports, Chio, Smyrna, Mount Athos, Dardanelles, Constantinople, and Odessa.
Arrivals at Alexandria every other Monday early in the morning.
Departures from Alexandria on Wednesdays at 4 p.m.
Crimean or Bessarabian table wines free.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1906..

div.head: ISLAM IN LONDON.
div.p: The great mosque, which is to be erected in London, is to be worthy of the Capital of an Empire, which has more Moslem subjects than any other. The most impressive features of Mr. Chambers' new mosque are the stately dome and the lofty minaret from the circular balcony, near the summit of which the muerrin calls the faithful to prayer. In certain aspects the plan of a mosque bears a not remote resemblance to that of a Christian church. In the design much is left to the taste of the architect, but one thing absolutely necessary is that the worshippers as they pray must have their faces set towards Mecca. So much stress is laid on this matter that when the scheme for the erection of the mosque at Working was in preparation an officer of the Peninsular and Oriental Company actually went down to the spot and took strict bearings by which the architect was ruled. Similar measures will, of course, be taken in this instance. The plan of the mosque which London it about to number amongst its religions buildings will be approximately square. The most sacred part is the recess known as the Mihrab, set in the middle of the wall which the worshippers face. Roughly speaking, it would correspond to the chancel of a Christian church. Next in sacredness is the Mayaura, somewhat equivalent to our nave, which not even Moham- medans may enter unless they are in the. holiest of disposition, and in which are sat the Minbar, or pulpit, and the Dekke, or reading desk, from which the Koran is expounded to the faithful. The Mohamedan service, it may be mentioned, follows no hard and fast rule. It consists mainly of extempore prayers supplemented by the reading and exposition of the Koran by the "learned men" of the community. There are, of course, no seats in the interior, and each worshipper kneels on the carpet which be brings with him for the purpose and which may vary greatly in splendor or cost according to the rank or wealth of the worshipper. As is also well- known, a Mohamedan mast divest himself of his footwear and wash his feet before entering the building, from which unbelievers ate studiously barred. For the purpose of this feet- washing process, a fountain or reservoir of pure water is provided in the enclosed court which gives entrance to the mosque. Perhaps the best means of giving an idea of the outward appearance of this building is to state that the height of the minaret will roughly correspond to the height of one of the western towers of St. Paul's Cathedral, and that the width of the main façade will be about 30ft. narrower than the western front of St. Paul's as seen from Ludgate hill. There, in point of dimension, the resemblance ceases.

div.head: SULTAN'S SUCCESSOR.
SECRET MISSION TO EUROPEAN CHANCELLERIES.
div.p: The Sultan has sent one of his secretaries on a secret mission to the diplomatic Chancelleries of several European Powers. The object of the mission is to give information in connection with the question of succession to the Throne. The envoy is to point out the great danger of supporting the candidature of either Reshad the prêsent Sultan's eldest nephew, or of the eldest son of the Sultan, Abdul Aziz, who are Liberals. He is also to point out that the candidature of his Majesty's third son is alone desirable in order to prevent revolutionary complications.

div.head: MILITARY TAILORS.
div.p: EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.
RIDING BREECHES.
F. Phillips & Co.
LADIES' TAILORS.
(high class work only).
CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Fatal Scorpion Bite.
div.p: A fatal case of scorpion bite is reported from Cairo, the victim being a young native girl.

div.head: Post Office for Karnak.
div.p: A post office for correspondence and parcels will be opened at Karnak in the Markaz of Nmg Hammadi, on the 15th instant.

div.head: A Nilotic Tammany Hall.
div.p: The inhabitants of Beni Suef have lodged a protest with the Cairo Governorat against certain irregularities which occurred during the Municipal elections there.

div.head: Attempted Suicide.
div.p: A young Italian, twenty years of age, living at Sharia Nawatieh, Ramleh, attempted to commit suicide yesterday by swallowing pbenic acid. He has been taken to hospital.

div.head: Esbekleh Summary Court.
div.p: Some irregularities have been discovered in the accounts department of the Esbekieh Summary Court and some small sums appear to have been embezzled. Some clerks employed there have been arrested on suspicion.

div.head: Alexandria Municipality.
div.p: It was found quite impossible yesterday afternoon to get together the small amount of municipal councilors necessary to form a quorum for the meeting of the Delegation. The meeting was consequently postponed until Saturday.

div.head: Mehalia Postal Scandal.
div.p: It is announced that the Post Offre author- iries have discovered 1,400 letters concealed in the house of a postman at Mehalla el-Kubre. The stamps had been taken off. The enquiry folly proves the guilt of thé postman, who bas been arrested.

div.head: Motor Accident.
div.p: Yesterday we announced that an old native man had been run over by a motor car at Zaher, Cairo, and sustained shocking injuries while the motor car escaped. It appears, however, that its number was seen as the car rushed away, and the number was 45.

div.head: Parricide.
div.p: A few days ago a native youth of a village near Damietta stabbed his father in the belly and made off, leaving him in a precarious condition. Father and son had been on bad terms over some domestic matter. The criminal was arrested shortly afterwards, and taken to prison.

div.head: Gambling Egyptians.
div.p: It is reported than an Egyptian Prince and two well-known natives recently lost £62,000 while gambling at Vichy. One of these natives before he left for Europe is said to have dropped £8,000 at cards at San Stefano, and his share of the losses at Vichy amounted to £50,000.

div.head: Elementary Grammar.
div.p: A new edition of the children's grammar for the use of the 1st and 2nd primary year boys has been published. The authors of this useful work are Mohammed Tewfik Taher, teacher of English, Kbalil, Agha School, Cairo, and Osman Nada, teacher of English, Sheikh Saleh School, Cairo.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCEs in Cairo.
div.p: The band programme, which it was announced would be for yesterday (Tuesday) has been transferred to the concert to be given on Friday next, are the band of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons played in the Esbekieh Gardena last night, for the band of the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers.

div.head: Port Sudan.
div.p: The Sudan Government denies the statement made by certain newspapers, that goods for Port Sudan most go for the time being to Suakin. Goods are received at Port Sudan, where accommodation will be found for than pending the repairs of the railway, which was damaged by the recent washout.

div.head: An Italian Virago.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon an Italian carpenter of the Attarin quarter of Alexandria complained to the police that an Italian female, who lived near him, had quarreled with him and out of revenge, was in the habit of stabbing him with a knife and throwing stones at his head whenever he ventured into the street. An enquiry has been opened.

div.head: Salary Improvement Commission.
div.p: It is now the turn of the kevasses and servants of the Ministry of Finance to petition Lord Edward Cecil for a "rise," owing to the increased cost of living. The Salary Improvement Commission has issued instructions, by circular, to the Ministries and Administrations in rechanges to made with the new year. Lord Edward Cecil is back in Cairo.

div.head: Pro Macedonia.
div.p: A mass meeting of the Hellenic Colony was held in Cairo on Monday night to devise measures of relief for the families of the yictims of the Anchialoe holocaust. After an impassioned appeal by the Patriarch Photius and M. Rikakis, a subscription was opened which realized £110o, The subscriber include Messrs. Gianaclis. £200; Rostovitz Bey. 150 ; Nungovich Bey, 150; Kyriasi. 80; Parissi Bellem, 50; Fayoum Hellenes, 40.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Amasis arrived here this morning from Glasgow via Gibraltar and Malta, etc. with passengers, mails, and general cargo. The Ellerman S. S. Austrian, now on the berth for Liverpool, is fixed to sail for that port on the 20th inst.

div.head:
RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
MASSACRE AT WARSAW FEARED. THOUSANDS OF ARRESTS.

div.p: The troops searched 200 houses here yesterday evening, seeking the terrorists. One thousand been made. It is feared that should the terrorists not dsist from murdering policemen and soldiers which has taken place at Stedlce is inevitable. (Reuter)
In the search for terrorists, thousands of arrests, principally of Jews, have been effected. (Havas)

A deputation of citizens at Siedlce requested the Governor to order the troops to cease firing. The Governor's reply was that he would bombard the city, unless the revolutionary leaders surrendered. (Reuter)
The Tsar has signed a ukase ordering the sale of 11,000,000 acres of State lands to the peasants. (Feuter)
The murderess of General Minn has been hanged. The Governor of Siedlce threatens to bombard the town unless the-revolutionary leaders are delivered up to him. (Havas)
The insurgents were crushingly defeated in an attack on the railway near here. It is reported that 200 of them have been killed.
The Government it sending e cruiser to Havana.

div.head: CRISIS IN PERSIA. NEW NATIONAL COUNCIL.

div.p: According to a telegram from Teheran, a commission has been appointed to frame the regulations governing the elections for the new national council. It is proposed that the number of deputies should be 200. The Shah has refused to sign the decree giving effect to the proposals. ( Reuter)
The Shah has signed the reforms ordinance. Business has been resumed. (Reuter)
The Shah has signed the Reform Bill. (H.)

div.head: BELGIUM AND ABYSSINIA. THE COMMERCIAL TREATY.

div.p: It is stated that the treaty of commerce concluded between Belgium and Abyssinia includes the "most favored nation" clause. (Reuter)

div.head: SOUTH AFRICA. THE QUESTION OF UNION.

div.p: The Premier in a speech declared that the union of the Colony with the Transvaal was outside the range of practical politics. He would never agree to a project involving the extinction of Natal. The Opposition also opposes the suggestion. (Reuter)

The punitive expedition which started on the 21st June from Lagos in order to punish the natives of Southern Nigeria has ended successfully. The surrender of the rebels took place on 2nd August. Twenty five native troops were killed and 150 wounded in the operations. (Reuter)
Instrument Concerts
Every Night
On the Verandah of the
WINDSOR, HOTEL
Alexandria
From 6 to 12 p.m.
5 O'clock Tea Served on Verandah.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH.
SPECIALIST AGAIN SUMMONED.
div.p: Although it was declared that the Sulten had almost recovered, the specialist, Dr. Berg- mann, has been summoned here for consultation. (Reuter)

Referring to the article appearing in our issue of the day before yesterday from the "North German Gazette" under the heading of "The Sultan," a correspondent writes from Cairo as follows : — Why does the "North German Gazette" in writing in praise of the Sultan of Turkey make the ridiculous statements that when he came to the Throne the country was in a state of financial collapse its army badly organized. The letter statement cannot be true. The army at that time was fighting and had been fighting against Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Russia, and Romania; in fact what may be considered the whole Slav race, and though it came out of it beaten, was not without a certain honor. Read Plevna, Brie room, and Kars. The financial collapse was brought about, as is well-known to all readers, by the attempt to westernize the East. Within four years of the termination of the Russo-Turkish war the coun- try was in a healthy, flourishing condition, and the peasants quite contented with their lot, Christians and Moslems working peacefully side by side. But the moment the present Sultan felt himself secure on the throne his grasping character began to make itself felt somehow or other he managed to sequester in so far as was possible the but estates for the benefit of the so-called Civil List, but in reality for his own privy purse. He tamed Yildiz Kiosk into an armed camp and practically kept all his intelligent and honest advisers as prisoners in order to centralize the whole power in his own hands and these actions entailed such enormous expense that all sorts of petty, vexatious, local taxes have from time to time been levied. The so called reforms effected by Abdoul Hamid have been the farming out of tithes, compulsory séquestration of cattle, the draining away of the best blood for the most disgracefully fed, clothed, and looked-after army in the world, except for a few thousands of soldiers around Constantinople who are under the personal supervision of German advisers. The finan- cial condition of the country was improved at the expense of the bond holders and in order that a few of the banks might make good profits, which were styled commissions, on the financial re arrangement by raising new loans at lower rates of interest end paying off the old ones. Railway concessions were granted with kilometric guarantees, such guarantees being again assured by increased internal taxes collected by the contributions indirectes, such concessions being given for personal reasons, whereas the older established companies would bave constructed the lines without guarantees, but refused to grease the palms of a ring of sharks from all the departments. Let the "North German Gazette" point ont one real reform during the thirty years of the Sultan's reign. The agricultural products of the country are not increasing pro rata to the area of undeveloped land for the simple reason that no Turk will cultivate more than is absolutely necessary for a living. The only flourishing lands are those belonging to the rayahs, who, although taxed like their neighbors, are exempt from conscription to an army, of which 20 per cent return to their homes in good health but unfit to resume their labours as cultivators of the soil. To turn to the mining industry. The country abounds minerals, but the opposition against mining, or rather against granting concessions to Europeans, is so great that, with the exception of a few concessions granted by his predecessor or in the early part of his reign, there are hardly any mines opened out, or if there are any they can only be got through the "Honest Broker." The Turkish peasant is a patient, steady, honest man, who is amenable to good government. His great religions favour can be and very often is worked upon to the point of fanaticism by a few narrow minded bigots who act as if they were still living in the early days of the Hejira and not 13 centuries later when other nations and other idea have come to the front Under an enlightened ruler, who would collect around him a few honest patriote inch aa existed at the beginning of the present Sultan's reign, who would raise the country to a standing based on a firm foundation, there is no reason that the Turkish Empire should not stand out before its Western neighbors in an example, and at the same time be the guiding light to Islam in reality, not in name only, as it is at present. None of the Powers desire the disappearance of Turkey aa a nation, but it is time that it understood that it is only draining its beat blood in trying to keep the cock-pit in order. Let them abandon European Turkey by giving them autonomy under the guarantee of all the Powers, and let them commence real reforms under conscientious advisers, in which case Asia Minor would once more become the garden of the world.

div.head: OPERA SQUARE AFFAIR.
div.p: This affair his developed into an international question touching the nationality of George Araghi end Alexander Koudsi, who have been sentenced to twenty days' imprisonment for assault on two British officers. It has led to an exchange of views between the Foreign Office and Hellenic Agency, as to whether they are Hellenes or Rayas. The "Zaher" quotes the Government as dissatisfied with the term of the sentence, and as having applied to the Agency to extend the penalty, in view of the brutality of the assault.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
RECEPTIONS AT VIENNA.
div.p: The Khedive has received Count Goluchowsky and the Marquis de Reverseaux. (Havas)

div.head: THE AKABA DEADLOCK.
div.p: Our Stamboul correspondent states that the present deadlock is due to the Turkish claim to the towns el Kassime, Haincadis, Metis, and Moukeiba, on the Red Sea coast at the head of Golf of Kassime. They base their claim on the fact that the Arabs pay tribute to the Turks, whence the Porte's prerogative.

div.head: PRINCE IBRAHIMS' ESTATE.
div.p: The following paragraph appeared in yesterday's issue of "Les Pyramides :- Nous avons dit hier qne la nomination d'un tuteur poor les enfants du regretté prinoe Mohamed bey Ibrahim u'aurait liao qu'après le retour de Soo Altesse le Khédive. Le Progrès se dit en mesure d'affirmer que oette nomination n'aore pas lien avant la rentrée do comte Cromer en Egypte.

div.head: BULGARIA AND EGYPT.
div.p: A Bulgarian firm, known as Eutcheff and Tzatcheff, has been founded at Varna for exporting Bulgarian wares to Egypt, where they intend opening an agency at Alexandria.

div.head: MOSLEM MARRIAGE LAW.
div.p: A divorced wife recently took proceedings in the Mehkemeh Sharieh against her husband, claiming her "nafaka." The Mehkemeh ruled that the nafaka should be paid; and as the husband possesses nothing except a house, the Mehkemeh sold it in order to cover the claim of the divorced wife's nafaka. The poor husband being greatly enraged by the judgment attempted to commit suicide by taking draught of phenic acid, and in spite of prompt medical treatment he is in a very precarious state. The German Courts have lately had to consider the question of the validity of a Turkish divorce pronounced in these circumstances : a German subject goes to Constantinople, there becomes a Musulman, and it naturalized as a Turkish subject Constantinople becomes his domicile, and there it no question of naturalization in fraudem legis. Originally married in Germany according to the Lutheran rites, be divorced his wife according to Turkish law, and married again. The Court below laid down a clear principle : the marriage was originally monogamic, and could not be changed by the act of the hatband into a relation which it depended upon his free will to continue or not Court above pat it on a narrower ground. It laid stress on the circumstance that the wife was in German -territory at the time of the alleged pronouncement, and that the "bill of divorce" was sent through the post to Berlin ; the transaction was in part in German territory.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: A European, of the Hamamil quarter, was admitted to the Government Hospital at Alexandria yesterday suffering from bubonic plague.

div.head: QUARANTINE.
div.p: The following telegrams were received yesterday by the Quarantine Board :-
Péra, 11 Septembre 1906. Pèlerins, voysgeort, Suez 48 heures observation Abon Saad.
Chypre, 11 Septembre 1906. Alexandrie exemptée de quarantaine. Visite médioale imposée aox provenances d'Bgypta désinfection des effets du passagers de pont d'origine égyptienne

div.head: THE SHOUBRA CRIME.
div.p: Paillard senior was examined yesterday at the French Consoler Court The following officiel communication was issued to the Press yesterday by the French Consulate: Après on long interrogatoire, M. Paillard père a fait du déclarations très nettes en oe qui concerne l'emploi dp son temps le jrordn mime et depuis cette date. Cea déclarations paraissent mettre u responsabilité personnelle bois i osc se. 11 adonné des justifications so sujet de la banknote de L.E. 60 qu'il a touchée à la National Bank et envoyée ensuite à Ahmed bey Ragheb.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: Mr. Morzani, Acting Italian Contai at Alexandria, will preside at the fêtes organized by the Casino for the 20th, the Italian national fête ; the proceeds go to the Italian Benevolent Fond. The Philodramatic Ernesto Roui Society w II give e patriotic performances in the New Theatre ; entrance free. Tomorrow afternoon, there is a concert at 5.30, and variety show in the New Theatre. There will be a small dance to-morrow. The mena of the dinner to-morrow evening will be u follows:-
Crérne do volaill. Sevigne
Liup de roche au bleu Sauce Hollandaise
Pomme Nature
Quartier de pre sale a la Printaniere
Pilaff a la St. Hubert
Légumes a la Orientale
Volaille rôtio créme
Salade
Bombe Palmyro
Uauftrotte
Grand Drtssrt

div.head: GROWTH OF FLOUR IMPORTS.
div.p: Those of our members who take the trouble to read our monthly article on the Customs returns will have noticed during the past year repeated allusions to the growth of the flour imports. They will also have observed that from time to time we have endeavored to persuada home millers and exporters to examine the position with a view to entering the market. Although was believe our remarks have been the cause of one or two firms opening out here, there is still room for farther enterprise in this direction. The following, table above the total imports into Egypt of floor daring the past five years.
The following was the average price per 1.000 Kilos c.i.f Alexandria during these five years respectively : — LE. 7.85, LE. 7.79, LE. 7.88, L.E. 7.96, and L.E. 8.14.

It will be observed from the above that while the quantity imported has increased, the average price per 1.000 kilos c.i.f. Alexandria has also risen since 1902. Taking for a moment the 1905 figures, we find that ont of fifteen different sources of supply the undermentioned were the five principal ones.
France Kilos 78.164.838 L.E. 620.283
Other Countries „ 5.975.561 „ 50.190
The total kilos were 121.422.087, a total value of L.E. 989.465.

The second of the above tables clearly indicate that the bulk of the trade (62.6 %) is in the hands of the French, and that England's share it practically microscopic. It is, however, gratifying to find that the Home Country's shipments have shown a considerable expansion during the past eighteen months, and that an effort is being made to recapture some of the trade formerly held by us. Whereas we were only credited with L.E. 7,811 in 1904, the figures rose to LE. 31,520 during 1905, whilst for the first half of the current year the clearances were veined at about L.E 38,000. There is thus a probability that the returns for 1906 may rival those of 1900, when England shipped 8,909,864 kilos= LE. 67,628 to Egypt, being the largest quantity ever sent over in any one year. The principle quality of French floor told on this market it the one known as "Soft White,'' the price running from 20 to 21 franca the 100 kilograms (220 lbs) f.o.b. Mantilles. The "Hard White" ranges from 19 francs to 23 francs the kilo, whilst the lower grades begin at 17/- the kilo. The English floor is sold in sacks of 280 lbs. the usual price being from 21/- to 23/6 per beg c.i.f. Alexandria. The duty payable to the Customs it the ordinary ad valorem one of 8 %, there being alto about ½ % for quay duties if landed at Alexandria. The flour trade is one of the few branches of Egypt's imports which are done on a cash basis so far as the country of origin is concerned. The merchant here as a rule either opens a credit abroad, or pays cash against documents. The bakers end retailers, of course, have credit facilities from the merchants, the usual term running from 30 to 60 days. As far as we can see there are no insuperable difficulties against the sale of English floor in Egypt, if proper steps be taken to introduce and push the same. There is, however, no denying the fact that the trade is a risky one, and that on a falling market the buyers are very apt to find soma excuse for securing a substantial discount, or for refusing delivery. Great care must be taken to deal with reliable men whether as merchants buying for their own account, agents selling on behalf of the miller, or the actual local users. It is perhaps not necessary to mention the importance of providing against any variation in the quality of the shipments. 7 The two main complaints we have received in connection with English floor are (1) the delay in receiving the goods owing to irregular sailings, especially from the Northern ports and (2) the damage done by rats daring transit, in consequence of the bags not being strong enough. With regard to No. 1, the millers are better able to suggest a remedy than the writer, whilst in the case of N°. 2 the answer is obvious. (British Chamber of Commerce.)

div.head: EGYPTIAN GLASS IMPORTS.
div.p: According to a bulletin to a by the French Chamber of Commerce at Alexandria, Egypt, the glass trade of the country is quickly increasing, the value imported last year amounting to E140,000, compared with E40,000 in 1892. The rapid increase is owing to a variety of circumstances, chiefly the great influx of Europeans, who do not care to employ the earthenware table utensils so largely used by the natives. There has, however, been a considerable improvement in this respect among the native population, and glass is behing extensively employed for all purposes. Glass ornaments, mostly bracelets, are greatly prized by the native women, while the increase in the use of oil for lighting purposes has given rise to a large demande for glass chimneys, three-fourths of which come from Bohemia and one-fourth from Germany. Bottles for mineral waters are largely imported from England, being delivered in Alexandria at about E1 per gross.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly Pasba visited Sheikh | Selim El Bi-bri, President of Al Azhar University, on Monday afternoor.
Ghazi Makhar Pasha is now in Vienna
Abdal Aziz Pasha lanet, Under Secretary of State for Poreigo Affairs, retorne here on October, from his leave.
Negoib Bey Ghali, of the Foreign Office, ia expected back next Toesday.
Ahmed Pasha Khairy, Director Ganeral of the Wakfa, arrived here yesterday.
Mr. Douglas W. Pollock will act in the absence of Mr. P. Rodeok, chief inspector of the Government Works Department.
Captain R. C. Wilson, RAM.C., arrived at Cairo on the 7th inat., from Port Said, where be arrived by the 8.1. Irene, from Cypros.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions el.
pressed by our correspondents, but we wlah, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permalt -within certala necorary limite free discussion.

div.head: RESPECTING ANTHEMS.
div.p: |To the BDITOR OF THE "EQYetiAN GAZETTE." | Bir.-On my retoro from the village where

I have been deprived of the pleagora of moud ing your estimable paper, I found among other interesting matter in your nombor dated lot September the letter from '. Cairo sorreopondent in which he oritioison that of mine, wbioh appeared in your inne of 30th oltimo, negarding the onseemly onduct of Englishmen at the publio playing of the Egyptian National Anthem. It would appoar that your oor respondent has not been "twenty years" oot of his own country, otherwise he would porhaps have known that it never we the oustom of the Egyptian population, and for that matter of other foreigners to pay respecta to National Anthems of any country, even their own, this being a habit that is only inbred in the Britisber, of which he has the monopoly. If your correspondent more to read my letter carefully he would observe that I made rofar. ence to the civilian Eagliabman. I am yet to learn that the condoot of Bogliahme is to be gaided or regulated by the action of the nativos, bat am under the impression that wa are bere for the expres parpose of forming and itproving the morals, manners and admi. nistrative capacity of the Egyptiads. Because a dative shows valgarity or want of taot, there is no reason wby we should imitate him as suggested by your correspondant. I am rather aarprised, too, that yoar correspondent should think that the Egyptian "Gentlemen," who showed such bad taste on the terrace of the Continental Hotel on the 29th Aagost, ahoold affect to represent the cream of their society, As it is well known that any one who imagine himself to be the croam of the Egyptian Society bus long since been in Earope, the milk in Ramleb, and the very poor skimmed milk only remains in Cairo. Byen most of the Government employes do not rotarp until the and of September.

1 shall make it a point of being prosent at the next pablic musioal entertainment, given by a military band, in the hope that an im. provement in the condoot of civilian Bogliahmon has taken place as a mult of my letter, w it woald appear to have had some offeot, by the fact of your correspondent stating that on Wednesday Every Englishman prosent rose to bis feet, when the Khedivial Athem was being played, whereas on former occasions I can sagore you that it was not 80, otherwise I abould not have written to yon on the sabjoot. --Yours faithfally.
"A Twenty years' Resident in Bg ypt." Cairo, September 11.

div.head: PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA. (TO THE EDITOR OF THE "Bayprian GAZETTE")
div.p: Dear Sir,-01 course I did not know, and I qoestion if anyone else in Egypt know, "exoept Mr. Rodolph," that the system I advocated in connexion with the arrival of "andesirables" in this country, was being aarried out. It has never, as far as I know,-and I am a daily reader,-been mentioned in the "B, G." Bven during the present "orasade, no mention has been made of the stops that are taken in thia direction. However, if Mr. Radolph aye Bo, no doubt it is true, although I mustay that tho persona no employed are evidently doing their daty under the anal conditions in Egypt, as there are now arrivals of this alaus every "ouson" in Cairo. I meat nothing

paronal" or "offansiyo" in mentionist Mr. Radolph's name in connerion with this matter, bat having visited bia Homo" in Cairo, aad soeing the letter be wrote to the BG.nome day ago, in which he statod, he had been "notling those young penons for such a pomber of yean, it struck me that thorou a great difference betwoon keoping a "home" for "govern.." whilst waiting for employment, and "bonting round well known member of the "Demimondo," and I still maintain that thon in. I thank Mr. Rudolph for the interesting sketch ot bis life, with which he has filled 97 colamda of the E. G."
Yoon faithfully
J. P. Cairo, September 10th,
